Description: Typical range for pulsed Nd:YAG lasers in wood cleaning to avoid thermal damage; starting at 50 W for light contamination on softwoods like Fir. Max limited to prevent charring (Fir's low thermal conductivity ~0.12 W/mK increases heat buildup). Source: Manufacturer specs from IPG Photonics and Coherent for industrial cleaning heads; academic paper by Pou et al. (2004) in Optics and Lasers in Engineering.
Near-IR wavelength for optimal absorption in Fir wood contaminants
Beam spot diameter for precise cleaning control on Fir wood grain
Optimal repetition rate for efficient cleaning coverage on Fir surfaces
Nanosecond pulse duration for efficient contaminant removal with minimal substrate damage
Optimal scanning speed for uniform cleaning of Fir surfaces
Recommended number of passes for complete contaminant removal from Fir
Optimal beam overlap percentage for uniform cleaning coverage
